50 0 0 OPD 11/7/2017 12:00:00 20171107120000 Nov 07, 2017 1100-1200 Advance Your Strategic Thinking Skills: Methods to Master the Building Blocks

A major provision of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) of 2017 is to increase Army personnel by 28,000. What does that all mean to TRADOC and how do we build Soldiers to the timelines as the NDAA mandates? In this forum, Mr. Paschal will discuss the many intricacies and complexities of the building process as well the impacts across TRADOC and the Army.

ARCIC will host General (US Army Retired) Jack Keane, former Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, for the next Distinguished Speaker Series on 26 October 2017 at the Fort Eustis Club. The event will consist of a keynote address and discussion on "Leadership in a Complex World". This is a great opportunity to discuss leadership in our increasingly complex world with one of our Army’s most influential leaders. We kindly ask any current or former senior leadership to RSVP to the Point of Contact below at joseph.c.bell2.mil@mail.mil not later than 19 October.

Read Ahead:
www.foreignaffairs | academic.oup.com | www.themonthly.com | www.wsj.com | www.nationalreview.com
The more important Asia has become on the global stage, the more glaring have its flaws become. The region is deeply fractured, threatened by economic stagnation, political upheaval and flashpoints that could trigger new wars. And in our more integrated global society, its troubles could quickly become everyone else’s. Much of the world’s attention in the coming decades will be devoted not just to accommodating Asia’s growing power but to managing and mitigating its growing risks. Fort Eustis, VA Wylie Theater 2017-01-26_OPD_01 Yes Yes LTC Steven Delgado REF Outreach and Assessments Chief Rapid Equipping Force, US Army Training and Doctrine Command TBDAsy LTC-Steven-Delgado_01 Army Training and Doctrine Command’s Operations, Plans and Training CPT Seth Fort 757-501-5801 seth.r.fort.mil@mail.mil TBD TBD Empty 39 0 0 DSS 12/01/2016 12:00:00 20161201120000 December 1, 2016 1430-1600 Strategies of Conquest and Control in the Sown, the Steppe, and the Wilderness: Landscapes, Logistics, and Governance Military historians and military planners tend to focus on military operations associated with initial conquest: marches, battles, sieges, perhaps raids, devastations, etc. For most of history, such "operations" were intended to expand the resource base of the aggressor. They were about conquest and the ensuing rearrangement of political authority that benefited from that resource base. Historians and military planners have spent less time thinking about how a conquering society accomplishes that rearrangement and resource extraction. How does the winner manage or control those territories or peoples after an initial military victory? Furthermore, most military historians examine conquest by and of hierarchical sedentary agricultural societies, mostly states. This presentation compares agricultural states to tribal societies on the steppe and in the wilderness, and examines how the landscapes affect the logistics of conquest and control. In the end, the strong role of the military in a post-conquest rearrangement of political authority means that logistical systems are key to shaping strategies of control. Fort Eustis, VA Morelli Auditorium, Building 950 2016-09-15_OPD_01 Yes Yes Colonel Greg Penfield Vice Provost for Learning Systems The Army University ../App_Documents/Bios/COL-Gregg-Penfield.pdf Asy Col-Gregg-Penfield_01 Training and Doctrine Command’s Operations, Plans, and Training Major Corey Hill 757-501-5806 corey.d.hill8.mil@mail.mil TBD TBD Empty 36 0 0 PDF 09/23/2016 12:00:00 20160830120000 September 23, 2016 1500-1630 The New German Security Policy and the Future Role of the Bundeswehr The 2016 White Paper on Security Policy and the Future of the Bundeswehr is the key German policy document on security policy. It is a strategic review of the current state and future course of German security policy. It is thus the principle guideline for security policy decisions and measures of the country. It establishes a framework in terms of concepts and content and provides starting points for strengthening the whole-of-government approach and developing further ministerial strategies. The White Paper defines Germany’s ambition to play an active and substantial role in security policy. It reflects Germany’s identity and understanding of security policy. On the basis of German values, national interests and an analysis of the security environment, it defines Germany’s strategic priorities and translates them into key areas of engagement for German security policy. Hill 757-501-5806 corey.d.hill8.mil@mail.mil TBD TBD Empty 34 0 0 DSS 08/19/2016 12:00:00 20160819120000 August 19, 2016 1430-1600 Enabling Practitioner-driven Innovation: Balancing Genius with Mastery The majority of research about new innovation models focus upon generating revolutionary grand design shifts as a way to assure military dominance. Left largely under-appreciated in current dialogue, however, are the accompanying processes of adaptation and improvisation and their impressive roles in driving military change. In particular, new innovation models overemphasize the role of "private industry genius" without examining the means by which preexisting organizational knowledge is required to transform contemporary practices with future war fighting potential. Drawing on historical and contemporary case studies across the U.S. Armed Services, this presentation invites consideration of the relationship among these processes in order to try to rebalance the discourse on military innovation. Ulses Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations, Plans, and Training US Army Training and Doctrine Command (TRADOC) G-3/5/7 ../app_Documents/Bios/Ulses-bio.pdf Ulses_01 US Army Training and Doctrine Command (TRADOC) Major McKeal "MIKE" Rodgers 757-501-5805 TBD Empty 31 0 0 DSS 06/17/2016 12:00:00 20160617120000 June 17, 2016 0900-1030 The Evil We Know: The Future of Putin's Russia and Russia Without Putin A new world began when the Iron Curtain fell. In the years that followed, celebration and unification masked growing complacency in the West. Russia failed to build democratic institutions strong enough to outlast its first elected president and just nine years after the USSR ceased to exist, Russia elected Vladimir Putin. Sixteen years later, Putin continues to challenge the free world wherever he can, from Ukraine to Syria. Meanwhile, he is turning Russia into a possibly dangerous regime-one that is increasingly well-funded with active conventional forces. But there are various groups that could act against him should the opportunity arise. Garry Kasparov will discuss Putin's motivations, goals, and tactics, and what the most likely scenarios are for a post-Putin future in Russia. Chasse (757) 501-6380 corey.b.chasse.mil@mail.mil TBD Empty 19 0 0 DSS 11/06/2015 12:00:00 20151106163000 November 6, 2015 1430-1600 Ghost Fleet: What Can Fiction Tell Us About the Future of War The United States, China, and Russia eye each other across a 21st century version of the Cold War. But what if it ever turned hot? In the spirit of early Tom Clancy, Ghost Fleet is a page-turning imagining of how World War III might play out. But what makes it even more notable is how the book smashes together the techno thriller and nonfiction genres. It is a novel, but with 400 endnotes, showing how every trend and technology featured in book— no matter how sci-fi it may seem — is real. It lays out the future of technology and war, while following a global cast of characters fighting at sea, on land, in the air and in two new places of conflict: outer space and cyberspace. Author P.W. Singer will speak to ARCIC about the book and its lessons for the future of war. Fort Eustis, VA Fort Eustis Club 2015-08-31_DSS_01 Yes Yes P. W. Dolan (757) 501-6357 peter.p.dolan.civ@mail.mil http://smallwarsjournal.com/jrnl/art/twelve-lessons-from-sixteen-months-reflections-of-a-cjtf-hoa-commander TBD Empty 17 0 0 DSS 8/21/2015 12:00:00 20150821163000 August 21, 2015 1430-1600 The Challenges of the "Now" and What they Mean for America's Land Forces As the Army prepares to win in a complex world it is important to understand what that world will probably look like from a warfighting perspective. This presentation synthesizes my work on Israel in Lebanon and Gaza, U.S. operations in the 2008 Battle of Sadr City, and the importance of armor in combined arms operations across the range of military operations. While the U.S. Army has been deeply engaged in two wars, the security environment has been changing. Our potential adversaries have capabilities that we have not confronted since the Vietnam War. Thus, the ultimate purpose of this presentation is to help the members of the Army Capabilities Integration Center better prepare our Army for the challenges the future surely holds. Fort Eustis, VA Morelli Auditorium 2015-01-26_OPD_01 Yes Yes Major General Cedric Wins Director, Capabilities Developments Directorate Army Capabilities Integration Center 0 Wins-Cedric-BG-ASU_01 US Army Training and Doctrine Command (TRADOC) Major Natasha Wayne 757-501-6323 natasha.wayne@us.army.mil 0 TBD Empty 7 0 0 DSS 1/6/2015 12:00:00 20150123160000 January 23, 2015 1430-1600 Naval Innovation in the Interwar Period 1920-1940 In 1914, the armies and navies that faced each other were alike right down to the strengths of their companies and battalions and the designs of their battleships and cruisers. Differences were of degree rather than essence. During the interwar period, however, the armed forces grew increasingly asymmetrical, developing different approaches to the same problems. This presentation of major military innovations in the 1920s and 1930s explores differences in exploitation by the seven major military powers. It investigates how and why innovation occurred or did not occur. This presentation also focuses on several instances of how military services developed new technology and weapons and incorporated them into their doctrine, organization and styles of operations.
